thread.title: Vast majority of 11 million illegal immigrants in US subject to deportation under new Trump administration guidelines
thread.title_full: Vast majority of 11 million illegal immigrants in US subject to deportation under new Trump administration guidelines

author: David Lawler
title: Vast majority of 11 million illegal immigrants in US subject to deportation under new Trump administration guidelines
text:
News Vast majority of 11 million illegal immigrants in US subject to deportation under new Trump administration guidelines Immigration and Customs Enforcement officers detaining a suspect during an enforcement operation on February 7, 2017 in Los Angeles, California Credit: Charles Reed/AFP David Lawler , Washington 21 February 2017 • 8:08pm 
T he vast majority of the 11 million illegal immigrants living in the US are at risk of deportation under new guidelines released on Tuesday by the Trump administration. 
Under Barack Obama, the department of homeland security only targeted people who had been convicted of serious crimes or were considered threats to national security for deportation. 
President Donald Trump has broadened the criteria to include any illegal immigrant who is even suspected of a crime, in addition to those who have been charged or convicted. The crime in question need not be serious- even those suspected of traffic violations could be targeted for deportation. 
While the administration says those accused of crimes will be "the first to go", nearly all of the 11 million illegal immigrants residing in the US are now at risk of immediate deportation. Donald Trump with John Kelly (R), the director of homeland security Credit: Peter Foley/EPA 
T he department of homeland security sought to stem the rising fear of looming “mass roundups” of illegal immigrants, saying “we do not need a rise of panic in the communities.” 
The official, who spoke to reporters on the condition of anonymity, said: “We do not have the personnel, time or resources to go into communities and round up people and do all kinds of mass throwing folks on buses. That’s entirely a figment of folks’ imagination. This is not intended to produce mass roundups, mass deportations.” 
The only group shielded from deportation will be so-called "dreamers", those who were brought to the US as children but do not have citizenship. 
"We're going to try and take care of the Dreamers very, very much," Mr Trump told MSNBC on Tuesday. 
The plan will also allow for expedited deportations for people who have been in the country for less than two years, regardless of where they live. Under Mr Obama, only those in the country for two weeks or less and living within 100 miles of the border were subject to expedited deportation. People participate in a protest against U.S. President Donald Trump's immigration policy and the recent Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) raids in New York on February 11, 2017 Credit: Stephanie Keith/Reuters 
T hat change will translate to new protocols for local law enforcement all across the country. 
Another change is that immigration enforcement agents can now deport those caught crossing the border directly to Mexico regardless of their nationality. 
The new policies are likely to lead to a substantial increase in deportations, but will require additional funds from Congress in order to be fully implemented. 
Mr Trump made victims of crime carried out by illegal immigrants a centrepiece of many of his campaign events, and has long spoken out about the dangers he says are posed by those who enter the country illegally. Watch | Donald Trump's Mexico border wall: in 90 seconds 01:30 
T he new policies included the creation of an office to help those affected by crimes committed by illegal immigrants, with the stipulation that “any and all resources that are currently used to advocate on behalf of illegal immigrants” be transferred to that office. 
Mr Trump also responded on Tuesday to a spate of threats made against Jewish centres across the US. He had previously deflected questions about a rise in antisemitism, telling one reporter he found it “insulting” to be asked about the issue. 
“The anti-Semitic threats targeting our Jewish community and community centres are horrible and are painful and a very sad reminder of the work that still must be done to root out hate and prejudice and evil,” he said on Tuesday. 
Ivanka Trump, the president’s daughter and a convert to Judaism, spoke out against antisemitism on Monday night. 
“America is a nation built on the principle of religious tolerance. We must protect our houses of worship & religious centres,” she wrote on Twitter. 
Mr Spicer was asked if Mr Trump would extend the same sentiments to Muslims who had experienced prejudice, but he spoke instead about the dangers posed by "radical Islamic terrorism." Follow Telegraph News
